context: Transmission electron microscope (TEM) images were taken at 80kV by a JEM-1230 (JEOL Corp., Japan). The thermal stability of MIL-101 was investigated by thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) with SDT Q600 (AT Corp., USA) by using approximate 7.3mg sample from 35°C to 605°C with a ramping rate of 2.0°C/min in air atmosphere. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectrum was determined using Bruker-vector-22 (German) with a range of 500–4000cm−1. MIL-101 sample for FT-IR analysis was pretreated by grinding power of MIL-101 together with KBr in an agate mortar and then by pressing them into flakes by a tablet machine.Adsorption measurements The vapor-phase adsorptions of BETXs and acetone were carried out at 25°C on a volumetric adsorption apparatus, i.e., Autosorb-1MP-VP (Quantachrome Corp., USA). This apparatus was modified with an additional organic vapor generation system and a heating system. The VOC vapors were generated by the vapor generation system at 50°C. The constant adsorption temperature was achieved by putting sample cell into water bath in Dewar flask.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, acetone is mentioned as a volatile organic compound (VOC) involved in vapor-phase adsorption measurements, while N(1)-methyl-2-lysergic acid diethylamide (commonly known as LSD) is not directly referenced in relation to acetone. The context primarily focuses on the thermal stability and adsorption characteristics of MIL-101, with acetone being one of the substances analyzed. There is no evident interaction or relationship between acetone and LSD in the provided information.
